channel.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
channel.description:
I want to know how to create (objects,may they be called?)like those of runescape,those graphics how do you create them?Do you need an external program to do this?Thanks for listening to my funny questions.
PS I don't understand some things in my java book: Q1)What is the difference between an argument and a comand line argument?
Q2)When they say [code]int howbad [] = {3,3,2,4} Err getErrorInfo(int i)[/code] What is the value of i?Is it initialized to a random number or what? If it needs more clarification please state,the program is [b]very[/b] long
Thanks for all the help.

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @the_one1 the one
item.description:
@the_one1 wrote:

No problem, I quite understand now, thanks.

Can I ask one more question?

In the example you just gave me, the value of int i is declared later,right?
In a if/for loop, my book always has something like this:

if(i<=0 i++)

That example was missing something,I know.But the main part is, they do not specify what “i” is, the only clue that I have is

int i

Ist that possible?

Read full topic
item.source: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

You dont really need to know much about the mothod signature, its just that if you want to call a specific method, you have to have the same number of parameters (usually only of concern in overloading a method).

Paramters are the variables (or arguments) the the method takes.

methodName(int i)

when you call the method you need an argument of type int (because of its signature). when you call it you will use something like int aValue = methodName(3);
so, “i” gets set to 3 (within the scope of the method)

sorry if i overcomplicate things

Read full topic
item.source: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @the_one1 the one
item.description:
@the_one1 wrote:

Well,the entire code is very long,and I returned the book today(from the library)
Now,I have more noob questions for you:
1)What do you mean by signature?
2)What do you mean by perimeter?
both these questions will tell you I’m still a noob,sorry 'bout that.

Now,as for the first question,what I mean is that when they do something like
blah blah (int i)
what does the i normally mean?Isit a value given by the class already,or is it a new number set to 0?Thanks for your time and sorry about the sloppy wording…

Read full topic
item.source: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

I have heard of Blitz, though never used it, if it interests you, have a go! it looks as though it will keep you interested long enough learn a bit about game making.

as for the questions, i dont know how correct my answers will be, but ill have a go anyway

  1. an argument would be a parameter of a function, eg function(argument1, argument2, ..., argumentN) and a command line argument would be a word used when running your application eg java myApplication argument1 argument2

  2. im not sure that i can analyse it correctly out of context, but int howbad [] = {3,3,2,4} looks to be declaring an array of type int that contains the values 3, 3, 2 and 4.

i am not sure about the function, so this will probably be totally wrong…

Err getErrorInfo(int i) is declaring the method signature of getErrorInfo()

  • it returns type Err
  • it takes one parameter, an int, which is presumably an error code to be handled

Read full topic

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

it doesnt matter, its what you feel comfortable with, though, vb and pascal are often thought of as introductory languages somewhat dont get me wrong, they can be quite good (take AR and SCAR for example) but C and java are much nicer. I too would like to learn BCEL and ASM, though not for a while as they are impractical to my current interests.

After somewhat wasting my whole cheating career with crappy command line java applications, im only getting into graphics now

haha and i would eventually like to try my hand at making a crappy 3d game aswell, currently looking at textbooks and webpages too see if they any techniques i can pick up… if i find anything suitable i must remember to pass them onto you.

Edit:
Theres nothing wrong with being 11 at least you are willing to learn, unlike the vast majority of this community. I, myself, tried to learn PHP at around 14, gave up then six months later tried again and succeeded, must have started java around 2 years ago, now that im 18 I often wish that i had a computer earlier so that i could have had a head start, so to speak

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_one1 the one
item.description:
@the_one1 wrote:

Ok,what I’m trying to learn is:
Java
VB.
Delphi
C
What is reserved for later learning:
BCEL.
ASM

As to graphics, I want to learn as I wanna create a sort of game using java, and maybe try out my own extremely crappy version of Runescape.

I am not very interested in web-programming languages now as I am, of course not very interested in web-based programming, however, the advantages you listed are quite good, must re-consider them.

According to your list,only 2 of my choices are in favour of you.Oh well.

PS I’m only 11 years old, I won’t go very far, so don’t blame me if at the end of the day I give you nothing in return…

Read full topic
item.source: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

It depends on what languages you know and what you plan to do with them.

Personally, I started of with web development, so I learnt html and some css, eventually learned javascript and php. I cant remember how long it took me, but I gave that up when I got into rsc cheating and learned java by fixing/editing scripts or by example.

If you already know a fair amount of java, learn how to do ‘basic’ graphics in applets then perhaps some advanced graphics programming, it all depends on how much time and effort you want to put into it.

In regards to 3d graphics, it depends what sort you actually want to learn, whether it is using J3D; a ‘real’ 3d graphics package, or, using a lot of trig and vectors (like runescape) to make your own ‘pseudo’ 3d graphics, or much simpler, some sort of isometric setup.

C# is alot like java in many aspects, but .Net is just horrible. I would like to learn C/C++ but havent had enough time to dedicate myself to it yet. The only procedural (you said you wanted to learn a non-OO language in your other thread) I have ever used is Scheme, which is quite horrible, but it can be intersting at times.

  • Javascript/HTML/CSS are good because they dont require anything special other than a web-browser.
  • PHP is good as it is fairly easy to use (once you have set up PHP and apache).
  • JAVA is just sexy, it’s great because it is an extremely OO language.
  • C/C++ sound goods because they are ‘relatively fast’ and its what most commercial devs use.
  • Scheme is used in first year university/college to introduce programming concepts as it is fairly easy to learn

Read full topic

item.title: Some questions, help answer please ,there on the second page, first page solved
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Java 3d references: http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,4608.0.html

But you can also use something like OpenGL for 3d programming in java:
http://opengl.j3d.org/
https://jogl.dev.java.net/

JavaWorld

3D graphics programming in Java, Part 3: OpenGL

The Magician Java-OpenGL binding, front-runner in the cross-platform Java binding-for-OpenGL standardization race, recently has been withdrawn from the market. Read about other choices on the market, and about the respective strengths and weaknesses...

And as for BCEL:
http://jakarta.apache.org/bcel/manual.html
http://jakarta.apache.org/bcel/apidocs/index.html
http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-dyn0414/ (The previous articles in the series may help with background info)

Read full topic
